We have previously shown that ΔN-ZntA, a truncated mutant of ZntA that lacks the amino-terminal domain, is an active ATPase with the same metal ion specificity as ZntA, demonstrating that the amino-terminal domain is not essential for function and that the transmembrane domain determines specificity (21Mitra B. Sharma R. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 7694-7699Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). However, ΔN-ZntA was less active than the full-length ZntA, suggesting that the amino-terminal domain may have a function in enhancing the overall catalytic activity, possibly by increasing the rate of metal ion binding to the pump. Studies on the isolated amino-terminal domains of a few P1-type ATPases, notably ATP7A and ATP7B, have shown that these domains can bind a variety of soft metals, including those that are not substrates of the full-length pump (17Lutsenko S. Petrukhin K. Cooper M.J. Gilliam C.T. Kaplan J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 18939-18944Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (213) Google Scholar, 18DiDonato M. Narindrasorasak S. Forbes J.R. Cox D.W. Sarkar B. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 33279-33282Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar, 19DiDonato M. Hsu H.-F. Narindrasorasak S. Que L. Sarkar B. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 1890-1896Crossref PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar). For example, the amino-terminal domain of ATP7B is able to bind Cu(I), a substrate, as well as Zn(II), Cd(II), and Hg(II), which are ions that are not substrates. Zinc binds to this domain with a stoichiometry of 6:1 and upon binding induces conformational changes that are completely different from those previously observed for copper. Spectra from x-ray absorption spectroscopy indicate that zinc is ligated primarily to nitrogen atoms, which is different from the behavior of copper-binding ligands of this domain. 3M. DiDonato, J. Zhang, L. Que, and B. Sarkar, manuscript in preparation. We therefore wanted to investigate the impact of interchanging the amino-terminal domains of P1-type ATPases with mutually exclusive metal ion substrates. In particular, we wanted to determine whether such chimeric proteins are active ATPases and if so, whether the amino-terminal domain is able to alter the specificity of the transmembrane domain. In this study, we have characterized the properties of chimeric proteins constructed by splicing the amino-terminal domains of the mammalian transporter ATP7B with the bacterial transporter ZntA lacking its amino-terminal domain. In one chimera the entire amino-terminal domain of ATP7B, including all six metal-binding motifs, was used; in the second, only the sixth metal-binding domain of ATP7B was used. The sixth metal-binding domain of ATP7B approximately corresponds in size to the amino-terminal domain of ZntA. Also, this domain has been shown to be sufficient for thein vivo transport function of ATP7B in yeast (22Forbes J.R. Hsi G. Cox D.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 12408-12413Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar). Both chimeric proteins were able to mediate resistance to lead, zinc, and cadmium salts in a zntA-disrupted strain but not to copper salts in a copA-disrupted strain. Thus, physiologically the chimeras behave like ZntA and not like ATP7B and CopA. Therefore, the amino-terminal domain of ATP7B cannot override the metal ion specificity of ZntA. Additionally, these in vivoresults suggested that the chimeric proteins are active transporters. This was confirmed by measuring the ATPase activities of the purified chimeras. Both WND-Cu(1–6)-ZntA and WND-Cu(6)-ZntA could be expressed in functional forms in E. coli, although WND-Cu(1–6)-ZntA appeared to be degraded to some extent in vivo. The purified hybrid proteins were able to catalyze the soft metal ion-dependent hydrolysis of ATP. The Kmvalues of MgATP for WND-Cu(1–6)-ZntA and WND-Cu(6)-ZntA for the Pb(II)-stimulated activity at pH 7.0 were similar to that of ZntA (90–160 µm). ZntA is specific for the divalent soft metal cations Pb(II), Zn(II), Cd(II), and Hg(II), with Pb(II) displaying the highest activity (20Sharma R. Rensing C. Rosen B.P. Mitra B. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 3873-3878Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar). The chimeric proteins showed the same substrate specificity, with Pb(II) again displaying the highest activity. In particular, no activity was observed with either chimera for Cu(I) or Ag(I). A comparison of the Vmax andKm parameters for the ATPase activities of the purified chimeras with those for the ATPase activities of ΔN-ZntA and ZntA in the absence of thiolates shows that the Pb(II)- and Zn(II)-stimulated activities of the chimeras and of ΔN-ZntA are ∼2–3-fold lower than those of ZntA. Interestingly, the Cd(II)-stimulated activity of WND-Cu(6)-ZntA is consistently higher than that of ZntA, ΔN-ZntA, or WND-Cu(1–6)-ZntA. We have previously reported that thiolates increase the ATPase activity of ZntA and ΔN-ZntA, possibly by increasing the rate of metal ion release from the transporter (20Sharma R. Rensing C. Rosen B.P. Mitra B. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 3873-3878Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar, 21Mitra B. Sharma R. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 7694-7699Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). The effect is most pronounced for the Cd(II)-ATPase activity. Thiolates were able to increase the activities of both chimeras for all three metal ions. The thiolate-stimulated activities of WND-Cu(1–6)-ZntA, WND-Cu(6)-ZntA, and ΔN-ZntA were highly similar to each other and 2–3-fold lower than those for ZntA (Table I). The thiolate-stimulated activity is likely to be a more accurate reflection of the in vivo activity of ZntA, given that glutathione is abundant inside the cell and that metal ion chaperones present in the periplasm may assume the role of thiolates. Thus, the data in Table I strongly suggest that the chimeric proteins resemble ΔN-ZntA in terms of their catalytic abilities. Therefore, the amino-terminal domain of ATP7B cannot replace that of ZntA in restoring full catalytic activity. It has been suggested that the full-length amino-terminal domain of ATP7B may play a regulatory role; metal ion binding releases an inhibitory interaction of this domain with the hydrophilic ATPase domain (33Tsivkovskii R. MacArthur B.C. Lutsenko S. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 2234-2242Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (135) Google Scholar). In this case, it would be expected that the WND-Cu(1–6)-ZntA chimera would be inactive until copper ions were added to the assay medium. In other words, we would observe copper-stimulated Pb(II)-ATPase activity for WND-Cu(1–6)-ZntA. Contrary to this expectation, Cu(II) in the presence and absence of dithiothreitol did not increase the Pb(II)-stimulated ATPase activity; it completely inhibited the Pb(II)-ATPase activity. This observation suggests that at least in the case of the WND-Cu(1–6)-ZntA chimera the amino-terminal domain does not play a regulatory role. We constructed two chimeric proteins in which either the entire amino-terminal domain of ATP7B or only the sixth metal-binding domain of ATP7B was attached to ZntA lacking its amino-terminal domain. The chimeras were able to mediate resistance to lead, zinc, and cadmium salts but not to copper salts in vivo. Thus, physiologically, they resemble ZntA. The purified chimeras were active ATPases. The soft metal cation-dependent ATPase activity was specific for Pb(II), Cd(II), Zn(II), and Hg(II), metal ion substrates of purified ZntA; the highest activity was obtained with Pb(II). There was no activity with Cu(I) or Ag(I), which are substrates of ATP7B. TheVmax values for the chimeras are ∼3-fold lower than the values for ZntA. Thus, the amino-terminal domain of ATP7B does not override the specificity of the transmembrane segment of ZntA. Also, it cannot replace the amino-terminal domain of ZntA in restoring full catalytic activity to ZntA.

The interaction of an 18-basecis-element in the 5′-untranslated region of human folate receptor (FR)-α mRNA with a cytosolic trans-factor protein is critical for the translation of FR (Sun, X.-L., and Antony, A. C. (1996) J. Biol. Chem. 271, 25539–25547). This trans-factor was isolated to apparent homogeneity as a 43- and 38-kDa doublet from human placenta using poly(U)-Sepharose, followed by preparative sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and electro-elution as major purification steps. Amino acid microsequencing of two cyanogen bromide-generated peptide fragments of the 43-kDa trans-factor revealed complete identity with 43-kDa heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein E1 (hnRNP E1). Purified specific rabbit anti-hnRNP E1 peptide antibodies (generated against a synthetic oligopeptide that was not represented in microsequenced peptides of the trans-factor) also recognized the purified trans-factor on Western blots. Conversely, the 18-base FR RNA cis-element also bound hnRNP E1 protein on Northwestern blots. Moreover, a 19-base RNAcis-element in the 3′-untranslated region of 15-lipoxygenase mRNA that is known to bind hnRNP E1 also interacted with placental 43-kDa trans-factor. In addition, several murine tissues containing a hnRNP E1-related protein (also known as αCP-1) readily interacted with the 18-base FR RNAcis-element. Finally, anti-hnRNP E1 antibodies specifically inhibited translation of FR in vitro in a dose-dependent manner, and the antibody effect could be reversed in a dose-dependent manner by either purifiedtrans-factor or hnRNP E1. Collectively, the data favor identity of the FR mRNA-binding trans-factor and hnRNP E1, confirm its critical role in the translation of FR, and highlight yet another role of multifunctional hnRNP E1 in eukaryotic mRNA regulation. Blood. 1992; 79: 2807-2820Crossref PubMed Google Scholar and 2Antony A.C. Annu. Rev. Nutr. 1996; 16: 501-521Crossref PubMed Scopus (500) Google Scholar). Human placenta is rich in FR and was the source from which FR were first isolated to apparent homogeneity as a truncated species (3Antony A.C. Utley C. Van Horne K.C. Kolhouse J.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 9684-9692Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) through the action of an endogenous metalloprotease (4Antony A.C. Verma R.S. Unune A.R. LaRosa J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 1911-1914Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 5Yang X.Y. Mackins J.Y. Li Q.J. Antony A.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 11493-11499Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). The full-length FR species that are anchored to the membrane by glycosyl phosphatidylinositol anchoring (6Verma R.S. Gullapalli S. Antony A.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4119-4127Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) play a crucial role in transplacental maternal-to-fetal transport of folate (7Henderson G.I. Perez T. Schenker S. Mackins J. Antony A.C. J. Lab. Clin. Med. 1995; 126: 184-203PubMed Google Scholar). Among the three FR isoforms (designated α, β, and γ), the most ubiquitous is the α-isoform (referred hereafter as FR-α). In studies designed to identify the basis for the inverse relationship between the extracellular folate concentration and FR expression (8Kane M.A. Elwood P.C. Portillo R.M. Antony A.C. Najfeld V. Finley A. Waxman S. Kolhouse J.F. J. Clin. Invest. 1988; 81: 1398-1406Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar), we identified that the up-regulation of FR in cervical carcinoma cells is primarily at the translational level (9Antony A.C. Li Q.-J. Sun X.-L. Xiao X. Tang Y.-S. Kuttan R. Kuttan G. Proceedings of the 19th Annual Convention of the Indian Association for Cancer Research & Symposium on Biology of Cancer. Thrissur, Kerala, India2000Google Scholar). 2A. C. Antony, Y.-S. Tang, M. P. Biju, X. Xiao, Q.-J. Li, X.-L. Sun, H. N. Jayaram, and S. P. Stabler, unpublished data. 2A. C. Antony, Y.-S. Tang, M. P. Biju, X. Xiao, Q.-J. Li, X.-L. Sun, H. N. Jayaram, and S. P. Stabler, unpublished data. Further studies identified a 46-kDa cytosolic protein in human cervical carcinoma cells, which specifically interacted with a CU-rich 18-basecis-element in the 5′-untranslated region (5′-UTR) of human FR-α mRNA, and that this interaction was critical for the translation of FR in vitro (10Sun X.L. Antony A.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25539-25547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Moreover, because this FR mRNA-binding trans-factor was widely distributed in cells expressing little to no FR-α, we predicted that this RNA-binding protein probably has additional functions that are unrelated to FR translation (10Sun X.L. Antony A.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25539-25547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). RNA-binding proteins are known to play a pivotal role in the metabolism, function, and fate of RNA in the post-transcriptional regulation of gene expression (11Klausner R.D. Harford J.B. Science. 1989; 246: 870-872Crossref PubMed Scopus (227) Google Scholar, 12Krecic A.M. Swanson M.S. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1999; 11: 363-371Crossref PubMed Scopus (709) Google Scholar, 13McCarthy J.E.G. Microbiol. Mol. Biol. Rev. 1998; 62: 1492-1553Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 14McCarthy J.E. Kollmus H. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1995; 20: 191-197Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar). In the past decade, several groups of RNA-binding proteins have been identified (15Ostareck-Lederer A. Ostareck D.H. Hentze M.W. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1998; 23: 409-411Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (157) Google Scholar, 16Cusack S. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 1999; 9: 66-73Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar) that are variously involved in mRNA stability, storage, splicing, transportation, and translational regulation. Accordingly, to characterize the FR mRNA-binding trans-factor (10Sun X.L. Antony A.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25539-25547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and further understand the role of this trans-factor in regulation of FR expression at the translational level, we isolated and characterized this protein from human placenta, which is a rich source. In this report, we present evidence that favors identity of the FR mRNA-binding trans-factor with heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein E1 (hnRNP E1). In addition, functional analysis of this protein using antibodies against hnRNP E1 confirms its critical role in the biosynthesis of FR at the translational level. The 1.1-kilobase pair full-length human FR-α cDNA, which was subcloned into the pSPT18 vector downstream of the SP6 RNA polymerase promoter, was designated pSPT18-FR-α (10Sun X.L. Antony A.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25539-25547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). To construct a plasmid containing the 18-base FR-α cis-element, sense and antisense oligonucleotides containing two 18-base oligonucleotide repeats with PstI andBamHI restriction sites at the ends were synthesized. After annealing the sense and antisense oligonucleotides and restriction enzyme digestion, the DNA fragment was subcloned into the pSPT18 vector between restriction sites PstI and BamHI. The new plasmid was designated as pXL37A. The 18-base sequence (see Fig.4A) was determined by DNA sequencing. To prepare the 18-base cis-element RNA fragment, pXL37A was linearized byPstI. To prepare radiolabeled RNA probe, [α-32P]UTP was included in the transcription reaction, and RNA transcripts were purified using NucTrap push-through Sephadex G-50 columns (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). 5′ end labeling was used to prepare γ-32P-labeled 18-base DNA oligonucleotide probes. Double-stranded 18-base pair DNA was generated by annealing equimolar amounts of single-stranded sense and antisense 18-base oligonucleotides by heating at 95 °C for 5 min followed by cooling to 22 °C. Chem. 1996; 271: 25539-25547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In some experiments, reducing or oxidizing reagents were added to the reactions to detect effects on the RNA-protein interaction. Briefly,32P-labeled cis-element (10,000 cpm) was reacted for 30 min at 22 °C with 20 µg of partially purified placental cytosolic extract (that had been dialyzed to remove dithiothreitol (DTT)) with various concentrations of dithiothreitol,dl-homocysteine, l-cysteine,N-ethylmaleimide, or oxidized dithiothreitol. After addition of RNase T1 and heparin and incubation for 20 min, RNA-protein complexes were electrophoresed (native PAGE) followed by autoradiography (10Sun X.L. Antony A.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25539-25547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). To semiquantitatively estimate the relative recovery of FR mRNA-binding trans-factor during each purification step, aliquots from each step were analyzed using a single preparation of 32P-labeled 18-base cis-element probe of known specific activity. The binding of a fixed amount of excess RNA probe with trans-factor present in each purification step was determined by a gel-shift assay. After drying the gel on Whatman paper, the areas of RNA-protein complexes (verified by autoradiography) were excised and immersed in 10 ml of Biosafe II counting mixture (Research Products International), and radioactivity was determined by liquid scintillation counting. Functionally active trans-factor was monitored during each purification step by Northwestern blots. Antony A.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25539-25547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Cytosolic protein extracts (S-100 fraction) from 5 × 107Hela-IU1 cells were prepared as described (10Sun X.L. Antony A.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25539-25547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Placental cytosolic extracts were prepared as follows. Full-term placentas were collected in an ice bath shortly after normal vaginal delivery and processed within 4 h of delivery. After removal of the umbilical cord, membranes, blood clots, and necrotic tissue, each placenta was diced into 2 × 2-cm pieces and then washed twice with 1000 ml of 75 mm potassium phosphate (pH 7.5) prior to homogenization in two volumes of 10 mm potassium phosphate (pH 7.5) (Buffer A). After centrifugation at 30,000 × g for 30 min, the supernatant was supplemented with 1 mm DTT and 0.5 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (PMSF) and filtered through a Minitan ultrafiltration system (Millipore Corp, Bedford, MA) using a 300,000 Mr cut-off. The sample was then concentrated over a 30,000 Mr cut-off membrane to a final volume of 50 ml/placenta. After the addition of 10% glycerol (v/v), the sample was frozen at −80 °C until further use. The protein concentration of the cytosolic extracts from human placenta (hereafter referred to as “crude sample”) was determined using the BCA method. Nuclear extracts from human placenta were also prepared as described (19Gorski K. Carneiro M. Schibler U. Cell. 1986; 47: 767-776Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (972) Google Scholar). Unless otherwise stated, all purification steps (Table I) were carried out at 4 °C and RNA binding activity was detected by Northwestern blot analysis. The crude sample was thawed to 4 °C and trans-factor was precipitated by 40% saturated ammonium sulfate. The pellet was rinsed with 40% saturated ammonium sulfate, following which thetrans-factor was dissolved in 10 ml of Buffer B (10 mm potassium phosphate, pH 7.0, containing 0.6m ammonium sulfate, 1 mm DTT, 0.5 mm PMSF, and 10% (v/v) glycerol). The sample was then loaded onto a 5-ml HiTrap phenyl-Sepharose CL-4B column that was equilibrated with Buffer B using a Pharmacia FPLC system. The eluted fractions containing RNA binding activity (fractions 5–9) were pooled and directly loaded onto a HiTrap heparin column (consisting of five 1-ml columns connected in series; Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) that was equilibrated and washed with Buffer C until the absorbance at an optical density of 280 was at base line. The proteins that remained bound to the column were eluted with 50 ml of Buffer B with KCl in a linear gradient from 0 to 1000 mm, and trans-factor-positive fractions (eluting between 0.3 and 0.4 m KCl) were pooled and diluted with an equal volume of Buffer C. After adding rRNA (35 µg/ml), tRNA (20 µg/ml), and RNase inhibitor (40 units/ml), the mixture was applied to a 5-ml HiTrap poly(U)-Sepharose 4B column, which was equilibrated with Buffer C. After washing the column with Buffer C until base-line optical density of 280 readings were obtained, the sample was eluted with 50 ml of Buffer C with KCl in a linear gradient of 0–1000 mm. Fractions of 0.5 ml were collected, andtrans-factor-positive fractions (eluting between 0.38 and 0.6 m KCl) were dialyzed against Buffer C using Slide-a-lyzer dialysis cassettes (Pierce). Finally, the sample was filtered (0.2 µm) and stored at −80 °C. Purified proteins (following the poly(U)-Sepharose step) were electrophoresed on 10% SDS-PAGE. Pre-stained protein markers (Bio-Rad) were loaded on either sides of the gel. Following electrophoresis, the band corresponding to the trans-factor was excised and the proteins were electro-eluted in 2-ml dialysis bags containing 25 mm Tris-glycine and 0.1% SDS. After filtration through 0.2-µm filters, PMSF and DTT were added to achieve a final concentration of 0.5 and 1 mm, respectively. Renaturation of the eluted protein from SDS-PAGE gel was carried out with minor modification (20Hager D.A. Burgess R.R. Anal. Biochem. 1980; 109: 76-86Crossref PubMed Scopus (813) Google Scholar). Briefly, four volumes of acetone (−20 °C) were added and proteins were allowed to precipitate for 30 min in a dry ice-ethanol bath. Following centrifugation at 12,000 × g for 10 min, the pellet was rinsed with 80% acetone. After drying at 22 °C, the pellet was first dissolved in 20-µl of 6 m guanidine HCl in phosphate-buffered saline for 20 min at 22 °C, followed by 50-fold dilution in Northwestern binding buffer (10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, containing 50 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA, and 1× Denhardt's solution in diethyl pyrocarbonate-treated water). The protein was allowed to renature over the ensuing 12 h at 22 °C, following which the protein was concentrated using Centricon concentrators (Amicon, Beverly, MA) and analyzed for trans-factor activity. In pilot experiments (see legend to Fig. 1D), several other renaturing buffers were employed in place of Northwestern binding buffer. After SDS-PAGE separation and trans-blotting onto polyvinylidene difluoride membranes (Immobilon-PSQ, Millipore) and staining, the band corresponding to the purified FR mRNA-binding trans-factor was excised. After cyanogen bromide digestion and separation of peptide fragments, or furtherO-phthalaldehyde treatment, two peptide fragments of the 43-kDa and one fragment of the 38-kDa species were microsequenced (ProSeq, Boston, MA). The results of microsequencing were analyzed within the GenBank™ data base using the BLAST program. The mRNA from HeLa-IU1 cells was isolated, and the coding region of hnRNP E1 cDNA was cloned by Access RT-PCR and EcoRI and XhoI sites were introduced into each end of the amplified cDNA fragments. After restriction enzyme digestion, the RT-PCR fragment was inserted intoEcoRI and XhoI linearized GST fusion protein expression vector PGEX4T-1. The recombinant plasmid was transformed to BL21 Escherichia coli, and a positive clone was verified by restriction enzyme mapping and DNA sequencing (Merlin Core Service, Carlsbad, CA), which confirmed that the insert was hnRNP E1. Following induction by 0.2 mmisopropyl-1-thio-β-d-galactopyranoside, the GST-hnRNP E1 fusion protein was purified by glutathione-Sepharose-4B affinity chromatography. Recombinant hnRNP E1 protein was released by cleavage of the fusion protein with thrombin (0.5 units/ml), and proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE, Northwestern blotting using32P-labeled 18-base mRNA, and Western blotting using anti-peptide hnRNP E1 antibodies. An oligopeptide containing a 19-amino acid stretch of sequences (SLAQYLINARLSSEKGMGC) of hnRNP E1 was synthesized, acetylated at its N-terminal end, and after conjugation with keyhole limpet hemocyanin, rabbit antiserum was generated against this antigen by Animal Pharm Services, Inc. (Healdsburg, CA). Rabbit anti-hnRNP E1 (oligopeptide) antibodies were isolated by affinity chromatography using oligopeptide-Sepharose, and stored in 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, containing 150 mm NaCl, and 1.0% sodium azide at −20 °C. Various proteins were analyzed by Western blots (21Nesbitt S.A. Horton M.A. Anal. Biochem. 1992; 206: 267-272Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar) using 1:10,000 diluted rabbit anti-hnRNP E1 (oligopeptide) antibodies that were detected with 1:10,000 dilution of horseradish peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-rabbit IgG (Promega, Madison, WI), followed by enhanced chemiluminescence detection and autoradiography. Female mice (C57 B6, 2 months old) were from Jackson Laboratories (Bar Harbor, ME). Placentas were obtained from CD-1 mice (Charles River, Wilmington, MA) on gestation day 17 and transported from Jefferson, AR, to Indianapolis, IN on dry ice. Murine tissues (bone marrow, liver, heart, kidney, brain, lung) were dissected and processed immediately after sacrifice. After S-100 fractions were prepared (10Sun X.L. Antony A.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25539-25547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 18Leibold E.A. Munro H.N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 2171-2175Crossref PubMed Scopus (555) Google Scholar), gel-shift assays and Northwestern blots were carried out using human 18-base cis-element. In vitro transcription and translation were carried out using the protocol (Single Tube Protein System 3, SP6) from Novagen (Madison, WI). Briefly, after addition (0.5 µg/reaction) of DNA template (BglI linearized plasmid pSPT18 FR) to the transcription mix, the reaction mixture was incubated at 30 °C for 15 min, following which aliquots of the transcription reaction were applied to the translation reaction. In vitrotranslation was carried out using a rabbit reticulocyte lysate system in a 50-µl reaction mixture containing 30 µCi of [35S]methionine. Various amounts of purified human placental FR mRNA-binding trans-factor (or purified recombinant hnRNP E1) and/or purified rabbit anti-hnRNP E1 (oligopeptide) antibodies (or nonimmune serum) were included in the reticulocyte lysate 15 min before in vitro translation was begun. The translation reaction was incubated at 30 °C for 1 h, followed by addition of 1 µl of 10 mg/ml RNase A. After incubation at 22 °C for 5 min, the reaction mixture was separated by 12% SDS-PAGE, followed by autoradiography. The 19-base sequence in the 3′-UTR of 15-lipoxygenase mRNA (25Funke B. Zuleger B. Benavente R. Schuster T. Goller M. Stevenin J. Horak I. Nucleic Acids Res. 1996; 24: 3821-3828Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar) corresponding to its cDNA (2116CCCCACCCTCTTCCCCAAG2135) was synthesized as follows. The sequence pAATTCG was introduced to the 5′ end of the above sense oligodeoxynucleotide, and pAGCTT introduced to the 5′ end of the antisense sequence. The resulting double-stranded DNA was subcloned into the vector pSPT18 linearized with EcoRI andHindIII to construct a plasmid pYST03. This plasmid was introduced into DH5α bacteria. To prepare the sense 19-base RNA fragments, pYST03 was linearized with HindIII, and transcribed by T7 RNA polymerase in the presence of [α-32P]CTP. γ-32P-Labeled, single-stranded 19-base 15-lipoxygensase DNA oligonucleotides were generated with the DNA 5′ end labeling kit (Roche). These radiolabeled 19-base 15-lipoxygenase sense RNA and DNA were reacted with placentaltrans-factor and hnRNP E1 and analyzed by gel-shift assays, Northwestern, and Southwestern blots. Using gel-shift assays to monitor the interaction of cytosolic extracts from human placenta with 18-base α-32P-labeledcis-element from the 5′-UTR of human FR-α mRNA, we identified an RNA-protein interaction (Fig.1A). With increasing cytosolic extracts, there were progressively stronger signals confirming a dose-dependent relationship (Fig. 1A,lanes 1–5). The abrogation of signals in the presence of proteinase K (Fig. 1A, lane 6) suggested that proteins were among the components that interacted with the probe. Northwestern blot analysis using crude cytosolic extracts from human placenta revealed a 43-kDa mRNA-binding trans-factor protein (results not shown). When equivalent quantities of S-100 cytosolic and nuclear fractions were analyzed on Northwestern blots, the 43-kDa trans-factor protein was predominantly found in cytosolic rather than nuclear fraction (Fig. 1B). Progressive purification of the trans-factor was assessed by Northwestern blots and SDS-PAGE. Various properties of thetrans-factor were exploited in its purification from human placental cytosolic extracts (Table I; Fig. 1C). Although the predicted molecular mass of thetrans-factor was 43 kDa, trans-factor proteins were retained by a 100-kDa cut-off membrane; this suggested its association in a complex with other proteins. Accordingly, following ultrafiltration using a 300-kDa cut-off membrane, the sample was concentrated over a 30-kDa cut-off membrane. Fig. 1C shows the progressive purification of thetrans-factor using the purification scheme summarized in Table I. Following ammonium sulfate precipitation, thetrans-factor, which bound to a hydrophobic interaction column (phenyl-Sepharose), was further purified based on its resistance to elution by up to 80% of Buffer C. Therefore, after eluting other proteins, the trans-factor was eluted by Buffer C, which was supplemented with 0.5% CHAPS. (CHAPS was selected because several other ionic, nonionic, or zwitterionic detergents (Nonidet P-40, SDS, Triton X-100) affected the RNA-protein interaction). Thetrans-factor interacted with the heparin column at pH 7.0, following which it was eluted by a linear gradient of KCl. The 18-base cis-element is a C/U-rich sequence (containing 11 cytosine and 6 uridine residues). Although thetrans-factor interaction with the cis-element could be competed by poly(C) (but not by poly(U)) (10Sun X.L. Antony A.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25539-25547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), the very strong interaction of the trans-factor with poly(C)-Sepharose precluded elution from this column with conventional buffers. Surprisingly, in the presence of CHAPS, we found that thetrans-factor could bind poly(U)-Sepharose and was eluted by a linear gradient of KCl. This was a key step in the purification scheme (Fig. 1C, lane 5). To eliminate minor protein staining bands (that were noted only on silver-stained SDS-PAGE) that co-eluted with the trans-factor following the poly(U)-Sepharose step, that portion of the gel containing the 43-kDatrans-factor was electro-eluted. An aliquot of this electro-eluted protein exhibited a single 43-kDa protein on repeat SDS-PAGE followed by silver staining. To prove that this protein was the trans-factor, another aliquot was denatured with guanidine and renatured and then assessed for the capacity to interact with the cis-element with gel-shift assays. As shown in Fig.1D, although there were no RNA-protein complexes when electro-eluted (denatured) 43-kDa trans-factor protein was assessed for RNA interaction, such RNA-protein complexes were best observed after the electro-eluted and denatured trans-factor was renatured with Northwestern binding buffer containing 1× Denhardt's solution (lane 9). Thus, the purified protein doublet that bound the 18-base RNA cis-element on Northwestern blots was the same protein that gave rise to the RNA-protein complexes on gel-shift assays. Accordingly, the electro-eluted, apparently homogeneous trans-factor was subjected to amino acid sequence analysis. After confirmation of apparent homogeneity based on SDS-PAGE, the trans-factor was characterized as follows. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 25539-25547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, using unstained Mr standards, the same 46-

Two high affinity Zn2+ binding sites were engineered in the otherwise Zn2+-insensitive rat γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) transporter-1 (rGAT-1) based on structural information derived from Zn2+ binding sites engineered previously in the homologous dopamine transporter. Introduction of a histidine (T349H) at the extracellular end of transmembrane segment (TM) 7 together with a histidine (E370H) or a cysteine (Q374C) at the extracellular end of TM 8 resulted in potent inhibition of [3H]GABA uptake by Zn2+ (IC50 = 35 and 44 µm, respectively). Upon expression in Xenopus laevis oocytes it was similarly observed that Zn2+ was a potent inhibitor of the GABA-induced current (IC50 = 21 µm for T349H/E370H and 51 µm for T349H/Q374C), albeit maximum inhibition was only ∼40% in T349H/E370H versus ∼90% in T349H/Q374C. In the wild type, Zn2+ did not affect the Na+-dependent transient currents elicited by voltage jumps and thought to reflect capacitive charge movements associated with Na+ binding. However, in both mutants Zn2+ caused a reduction of the inward transient currents upon jumping to hyperpolarized potentials as reflected in rightward-shifted Q/V relationships. This suggests that Zn2+ is inhibiting transporter function by stabilizing the outward-facing Na+-bound state. Translocation of lithium by the transporter does not require GABA binding and analysis of this uncoupled Li+ conductance revealed a potent inhibition by Zn2+ in T349H/E370H, whereas surprisingly the T349H/Q374C leak was unaffected. This differential effect supports that the leak conductance represents a unique operational mode of the transporter involving conformational changes different from those of the substrate translocation process. Altogether our results support both an evolutionary conserved structural organization of the TM 7/8 domain and a key role of this domain in GABA-dependent and -independent conformational changes of the transporter. Introduction of a histidine (T349H) at the extracellular end of transmembrane segment (TM) 7 together with a histidine (E370H) or a cysteine (Q374C) at the extracellular end of TM 8 resulted in potent inhibition of [3H]GABA uptake by Zn2+ (IC50 = 35 and 44 µm, respectively). Upon expression in Xenopus laevis oocytes it was similarly observed that Zn2+ was a potent inhibitor of the GABA-induced current (IC50 = 21 µm for T349H/E370H and 51 µm for T349H/Q374C), albeit maximum inhibition was only ∼40% in T349H/E370H versus ∼90% in T349H/Q374C. In the wild type, Zn2+ did not affect the Na+-dependent transient currents elicited by voltage jumps and thought to reflect capacitive charge movements associated with Na+ binding. However, in both mutants Zn2+ caused a reduction of the inward transient currents upon jumping to hyperpolarized potentials as reflected in rightward-shifted Q/V relationships. This suggests that Zn2+ is inhibiting transporter function by stabilizing the outward-facing Na+-bound state. Translocation of lithium by the transporter does not require GABA binding and analysis of this uncoupled Li+ conductance revealed a potent inhibition by Zn2+ in T349H/E370H, whereas surprisingly the T349H/Q374C leak was unaffected. This differential effect supports that the leak conductance represents a unique operational mode of the transporter involving conformational changes different from those of the substrate translocation process. Altogether our results support both an evolutionary conserved structural organization of the TM 7/8 domain and a key role of this domain in GABA-dependent and -independent conformational changes of the transporter. γ-aminobutyric acid GABA transporter rat GABA transporter-1 human dopamine transporter serotonin transporter betaine/GABA transporter-1 transmembrane segment wild-type choline chloride 4-amino-n-[2,3-3H]butyric acid γ-Aminobutyric acid (GABA)1 is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the mammalian central nervous system. Following release into the synaptic cleft the effect of GABA is rapidly terminated by reuptake into the presynaptic nerve terminal via specific transporter proteins present in the plasma membrane (1Miller J.W. Kleven D.T. Domin B.A. Fremau Jr., R.T. Reith M.E.A. Neurotransmitter Transporters: Structure, Function, and Regulation. Humana Press, Totowa, NJ1997: 101-150Crossref Google Scholar). These transporters play a critical role in regulating GABA-mediated neurotransmission by controlling the availability of GABA in the extracellular space. Currently four distinct GABA transporters have been identified (GABA transporter-1 (GAT-1), GAT-2, GAT-3, and BGT-1) (1Miller J.W. Kleven D.T. Domin B.A. Fremau Jr., R.T. Reith M.E.A. Neurotransmitter Transporters: Structure, Function, and Regulation. Humana Press, Totowa, NJ1997: 101-150Crossref Google Scholar). They belong to the large family of Na+/Cl−-dependent transporters, which also include the transporters for several other neurotransmitters such as dopamine, serotonin, norepinephrine, and glycine (1Miller J.W. Kleven D.T. Domin B.A. Fremau Jr., R.T. Reith M.E.A. Neurotransmitter Transporters: Structure, Function, and Regulation. Humana Press, Totowa, NJ1997: 101-150Crossref Google Scholar, 2Amara S.G. Kuhar M.J. Annu. Rev. Neurosci. 1993; 16: 73-93Crossref PubMed Scopus (991) Google Scholar, 3Kanner B.I. J. Exp. Biol. 1994; 196: 237-249Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 4Nelson N. J. Neurochem. 1998; 71: 1785-1803Crossref PubMed Scopus (321) Google Scholar). The Na+/Cl−-dependent neurotransmitter transporters are all believed to share a common topology with 12 predicted transmembrane segments and cytoplasmic amino and carboxyl termini (1Miller J.W. Kleven D.T. Domin B.A. Fremau Jr., R.T. Reith M.E.A. Neurotransmitter Transporters: Structure, Function, and Regulation. Humana Press, Totowa, NJ1997: 101-150Crossref Google Scholar, 2Amara S.G. Kuhar M.J. Annu. Rev. Neurosci. 1993; 16: 73-93Crossref PubMed Scopus (991) Google Scholar, 3Kanner B.I. J. Exp. Biol. 1994; 196: 237-249Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 4Nelson N. J. Neurochem. 1998; 71: 1785-1803Crossref PubMed Scopus (321) Google Scholar). In addition, they are characterized by a large glycosylated extracellular loop connecting transmembrane segment (TM) 3 and 4 (1Miller J.W. Kleven D.T. Domin B.A. Fremau Jr., R.T. Reith M.E.A. Neurotransmitter Transporters: Structure, Function, and Regulation. Humana Press, Totowa, NJ1997: 101-150Crossref Google Scholar, 2Amara S.G. Kuhar M.J. Annu. Rev. Neurosci. 1993; 16: 73-93Crossref PubMed Scopus (991) Google Scholar, 3Kanner B.I. J. Exp. Biol. 1994; 196: 237-249Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 4Nelson N. J. Neurochem. 1998; 71: 1785-1803Crossref PubMed Scopus (321) Google Scholar). The transport of GABA across the plasma membrane is driven by the transmembrane Na+ gradient maintained by the Na+/K+-ATPase. Na+ is co-transported with GABA, and the estimated stoichiometry of the translocation process in the GAT-1 is two sodium ions and one chloride ion per GABA molecule (5Keynan S. Kanner B.I. Biochemistry. 1988; 27: 12-17Crossref PubMed Scopus (132) Google Scholar, 6Kavanaugh M.P. Arriza J.L. North R.A. Amara S.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 22007-22009Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 7Lu C.C. Hilgemann D.W. J. Gen. Physiol. 1999; 114: 445-457Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). However, it is of interest to note that the co-transport of the Cl− ion recently has been disputed by Loo et al. (8Loo D.D. Eskandari S. Boorer K.J. Sarkar H.K. Wright E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 37414-37422Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar) who proposed that the Cl−dependence does not involve a co-transport of Cl− but rather a Cl−/Cl− exchange mechanism during the transport cycle (8Loo D.D. Eskandari S. Boorer K.J. Sarkar H.K. Wright E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 37414-37422Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar). Since the uptake of GABA is electrogenic (5Keynan S. Kanner B.I. Biochemistry. 1988; 27: 12-17Crossref PubMed Scopus (132) Google Scholar,6Kavanaugh M.P. Arriza J.L. North R.A. Amara S.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 22007-22009Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 9Mager S. Naeve J. Quick M. Labarca C. Davidson N. Lester H.A. Neuron. 1993; 10: 177-188Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (275) Google Scholar) the transporters have been subjected to electrophysiological measurements. The electrophysiological measurements have not only been able to define a voltage-dependent current stoichiometrically coupled to the translocation of GABA but also indicated additional operational modes of the transporter (9Mager S. Naeve J. Quick M. Labarca C. Davidson N. Lester H.A. Neuron. 1993; 10: 177-188Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (275) Google Scholar, 10Mager S. Kleinberger-Doron N. Keshet G.I. Davidson N. Kanner B.I. Lester H.A. J. Neurosci. 1996; 16: 5405-5414Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 11Bismuth Y. Kavanaugh M.P. Kanner B.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 16096-16102Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar). First, in the absence of GABA and in the presence of Li+, an inwardly directed leak current has been shown to arise at hyperpolarized potentials (10Mager S. Kleinberger-Doron N. Keshet G.I. Davidson N. Kanner B.I. Lester H.A. J. Neurosci. 1996; 16: 5405-5414Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 11Bismuth Y. Kavanaugh M.P. Kanner B.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 16096-16102Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar). Second, Na+-dependent transient currents were found to arise in the absence of GABA during voltage jumps of the membrane potential (9Mager S. Naeve J. Quick M. Labarca C. Davidson N. Lester H.A. Neuron. 1993; 10: 177-188Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (275) Google Scholar, 11Bismuth Y. Kavanaugh M.P. Kanner B.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 16096-16102Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar). These transient currents are believed to represent charge movements resulting from conformational changes associated with the binding and unbinding of Na+ ions as the conformational equilibrium is shifted following abrupt changes in the potential across the membrane (9Mager S. Naeve J. Quick M. Labarca C. Davidson N. Lester H.A. Neuron. 1993; 10: 177-188Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (275) Google Scholar, 11Bismuth Y. Kavanaugh M.P. Kanner B.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 16096-16102Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar, 12Parent L. Supplisson S. Loo D.D. Wright E.M. J. Membr. Biol. 1992; 125: 63-79PubMed Google Scholar). Finally, the presence of a relatively large uncoupled transport-associated current has been proposed based on apparent disparities between the net fluxes of substrate and charge translocation (13Cammack J.N. Schwartz E.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 723-727Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar, 14Risso S. DeFelice L.J. Blakely R.D. J. Physiol. 1996; 490: 691-702Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar). This putative uncoupled channel activity arising in the presence of substrate suggests similarity between neurotransmitter transporters and ligand-gated ion channels. Nonetheless, a tight coupling between charge movements and [3H]GABA transport has recently been demonstrated (8Loo D.D. Eskandari S. Boorer K.J. Sarkar H.K. Wright E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 37414-37422Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar). This observation together with the study by Lu and Hilgemann (15Lu C.C. Hilgemann D.W. J. Gen. Physiol. 1999; 114: 429-444Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar) may argue against the existence of such a channel mode at least in GAT-1. Many studies have been carried out in the attempt to identify functionally important regions in the GABA transporters as well as in other Na+/Cl−-dependent transporters (11Bismuth Y. Kavanaugh M.P. Kanner B.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 16096-16102Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar, 16Bennett E.R. Su H. Kanner B.I. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 34106-34113Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar, 17Chen N. Reith M.E. Eur. J. Pharmacol. 2000; 405: 329-339Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar, 18Adkins E.M. Barker E.L. Blakely R.D. Mol. Pharmacol. 2001; 59: 514-523Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar, 19Barker E.L. Blakely R.D. Methods Enzymol. 1998; 296: 475-498Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). These studies have resulted in the identification of several residues important for the interaction of substrate and blockers with the transporters and/or residues important for the translocation process (11Bismuth Y. Kavanaugh M.P. Kanner B.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 16096-16102Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar, 16Bennett E.R. Su H. Kanner B.I. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 34106-34113Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar, 17Chen N. Reith M.E. Eur. J. Pharmacol. 2000; 405: 329-339Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar, 18Adkins E.M. Barker E.L. Blakely R.D. Mol. Pharmacol. 2001; 59: 514-523Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar, 19Barker E.L. Blakely R.D. Methods Enzymol. 1998; 296: 475-498Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). Nevertheless, in the absence of tertiary structure information, it has not been possible to define, for example, the substrate and ion permeation pathways. Thus the molecular mechanism underlying translocation of the substrate across the membrane remains still essentially unknown. Recently we have been able to define the first distance constraints in the tertiary structure of a Na+/Cl−-dependent transporter based on the discovery of an endogenous high affinity Zn2+binding site in the human dopamine transporter (hDAT) (20Norregaard L. Frederiksen D. Nielsen E.O. Gether U. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 4266-4273Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar, 21Loland C.J. Norregaard L. Gether U. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 36928-36934Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). We were able to identify three Zn2+ coordinating residues in this binding site: His193 in the large extracellular loop between transmembrane segments 3 and 4, His375 at the external end of TM 7, and Glu396 at the external end of TM 8 (20Norregaard L. Frederiksen D. Nielsen E.O. Gether U. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 4266-4273Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar, 21Loland C.J. Norregaard L. Gether U. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 36928-36934Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). The three residues are distanced in the primary structure, but their common participation in binding of the small Zn2+ion defined their spatial proximity in the tertiary structure of the transporter. Based on the information provided from the endogenous Zn2+ binding site, a series of artificial Zn2+binding sites in the hDAT were subsequently engineered by taking advantage of the strict geometrical requirements for binding of the Zn2+ ion (22Norregaard L. Visiers I. Loland C.J. Ballesteros J. Weinstein H. Gether U. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 15836-15846Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). The information acquired enabled us to build a structural model of the “TM 7/8 microdomain” in the hDAT that improved the analysis and prediction of structural features in a functionally important region of this transporter (22Norregaard L. Visiers I. Loland C.J. Ballesteros J. Weinstein H. Gether U. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 15836-15846Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). In this present study we have genetically transferred Zn2+binding sites from the hDAT to GAT-1 to probe the structural and functional similarity between two distinct Na+/Cl−-dependent transporters and thereby use engineered Zn2+ binding sites as evolutionary fingerprints of structural and functional features conserved through evolution in this class of transporters. The engineering of two inhibitory Zn2+ switches in GAT-1 between TM 7 and 8 provided direct support for a similar structural organization of the TM 7/8 domain in GAT-1 as in DAT and indicated a common key role of this domain in the substrate translocation mechanism. Moreover, two-electrode voltage clamp measurements on GAT-1 and the mutated transporters expressed in Xenopus laevis oocytes provided both new insight into the molecular mechanism underlying the inhibitory effect of Zn2+ at the engineered Zn2+ binding sites as well as new information about the relationships between GABA uptake and the different transporter-mediated currents. The cDNA for rGAT-1 in pBluescript SK (23Pantanowitz S. Bendahan A. Kanner B.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 3222-3225Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) was mutated by polymerase chain reaction-derived mutagenesis using Pfu polymerase according to the instructions of the manufacturer (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). The polymerase chain reaction products were digested with the appropriate enzymes, purified by agarose gel electrophoresis, and cloned into either the mammalian expression vector pRc/CMV (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) or a vector optimized for oocyte expression (pNB1) containing rGAT-1 as HindIII and XbaI fragments. The vector pNB1 was generated by enlarging the multiple cloning site of pGH19, which is a modified version of pGEMHE (24Liman E.R. Tytgat J. Hess P. Neuron. 1992; 9: 861-871Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (966) Google Scholar). The mutations were verified by restriction enzyme mapping and DNA sequencing using an ABI 310 automated sequencer. The rGAT-1 constructs were transiently transfected into COS-7 cells by the calcium phosphate precipitation method as described previously (25Johansen T.E. Scholler M.S. Tolstoy S. Schwartz T.W. FEBS Lett. 1990; 267: 289-294Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar, 26Gether U. Marray T. Schwartz T.W. Johansen T.E. FEBS Lett. 1992; 296: 241-244Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). The cells were grown as described in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Life Technologies, Inc. catalog no. 0413 1855) supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum, 2 mml-glutamine, and 0.01 mg/ml gentamicin (25Johansen T.E. Scholler M.S. Tolstoy S. Schwartz T.W. FEBS Lett. 1990; 267: 289-294Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar, 26Gether U. Marray T. Schwartz T.W. Johansen T.E. FEBS Lett. 1992; 296: 241-244Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). For expression in HeLa cells, the cells were plated on 24-well plates and infected with recombinant vaccinia/T7 virus (27Fuerst T.R. Niles E.G. Studier F.W. Moss B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1986; 83: 8122-8126Crossref PubMed Scopus (1861) Google Scholar) and transfected with cDNA (pBluescript SK with the wild type or mutant transporter inserted downstream of the T7 promoter) using the transfection reagentN-[1-(2,3-dioleoyloxy)propyl]-N,N,N-trimethylammonium salts (DOTAP) as described previously (28Keynan S. Suh Y.J. Kanner B.I. Rudnick G. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 1974-1979Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar). The rGAT-1 constructs in the oocyte vector pNB1 were linearized downstream of the poly(A) segment with NotI and in vitro transcribed with the T7 RNA polymerase using the mCAP mRNA capping kit (Stratagene). The mRNAs were phenol/chloroform-extracted, ethanol-precipitated, and dissolved in Tris-EDTA buffer to a concentration of ∼1 µg/µl. The integrity of the transcripts was confirmed by agarose gel electrophoresis, and the mRNA was stored at −80 °C until injection. Female X. laevis frogs were anesthetized for 15–20 min in 2 g/liter Tricaine (3-aminobenzoic acid ethyl ester, Sigma catalog no. A-5040) before an ovarian lobe was removed from the abdominal cavity through a small (1-cm) incision. Oocytes were defolliculated enzymatically by incubation in 1% collagenase (Sigma catalog no. C-0130) and 0.1% trypsin inhibitor (Sigma catalog no. T-2011) in Kulori medium (90 mm NaCl, 1 mmKCl, 1 mm MgCl2, 1 mmCaCl2, 5 mm Hepes-Tris, pH 7.4) for 1 h followed by five washes in Kulori medium containing 0.1% bovine serum albumin (Sigma catalog no. A-6003) and incubation for 1 h in a hypertonic phosphate buffer (100 mmK2HPO4, pH 6.5). Subsequently stage V and VI oocytes were selected, washed five times in Kulori medium, and kept overnight at 19 °C in Kulori medium before injection with 50 nl of mRNA (∼50 ng) using a Nanoject microinjector (Drummond). Injected and noninjected oocytes were kept in Kulori medium at 19 °C for 3–7 days before electrophysiological measurements. The oocytes were incubated in Kulori medium at 19 °C for 3–7 days before experiments were performed. Uptake assays were carried out using 4-amino-n-[2,3-3H]butyric acid ([3H]GABA) (88 Ci/mmol) (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). Transfected COS-7 cells were plated in 12-well dishes (1–3 × 105 cells/well) to achieve an uptake level of 5–10% of total added [3H]GABA. The uptake assays were carried out 2 days after transfection. Prior to the experiment, the cells were washed once with 500 µl of uptake buffer (25 mm Hepes, 120 mm NaCl, 5 mm KCl, 1.2 mm CaCl2, 1.2 mmMgSO4, 1 mml-ascorbic acid, 5 mmd-glucose, pH 7.4). Uptake buffer and Zn2+ or unlabeled GABA were added to the cells, and uptake was initiated by the addition of 5 nm[3H]GABA in a final volume of 500 µl. After 10 min of incubation at 37 °C, the cells were washed twice with 500 µl of uptake buffer, lysed in 500 µl of 1% SDS, and left for 1 h at 37 °C. All samples were transferred to 24-well counting plates (Wallac, Turku, Finland), and 500 µl of Opti-phase Hi Safe 3 scintillation fluid (Wallac) were added followed by counting of the plates in a Wallac Tri-Lux β scintillation counter. Nonspecific uptake was determined in the presence of 1 mm nonlabeled GABA (RBI, Natick, MA). All determinations were performed in triplicate. The uptake experiments were performed in 24-well plates with 30 µm GABA and 15 nm [3H]GABA added to a total of 400 µl of oocyte uptake buffer (90 mmNaCl, 2 mm KCl, 1 mm CaCl2, 1 mm MgCl2, 10 mm Hepes-Tris, pH 7.4). Oocytes were incubated for 30 min at room temperature, washed three times in 1 ml of oocyte uptake buffer with choline chloride (90 mm ChCl, 2 mm KCl, 1 mmCaCl2, 1 mm MgCl2, 10 mm Hepes-Tris, pH 7.4), and dissolved in 200 µl of 10% SDS. Before counting, 2.0 ml of scintillation fluid was added to the samples. The [3H]GABA uptake experiments on the HeLa cells were carried out 18–20 h post-transfection as described previously (16Bennett E.R. Su H. Kanner B.I. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 34106-34113Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar). For oxidative cross-linking with Cu2+-phenanthroline, a fresh stock solution of 150 mm Cu2+-phenanthroline was made up for each experiment as follows. 600 µl of a 250 mmCuSO4 solution were mixed with 400 µl of a 1.25m solution of 1,10-phenanthroline in 50% ethanol. This stock solution was further diluted into the NaCl-containing transport solution to the desired concentration. Just prior to the transport assay the cells from triplicate or quadruplicate wells were washed twice with 1 ml of choline medium (transport solution with ChCl replacing the NaCl) and incubated with 1 ml of transport solution with or without Cu2+-phenanthroline at the indicated final concentrations for 5 min. Subsequently the cells were washed once in choline medium and assayed for sodium-dependent [3H]GABA uptake, subtracting values obtained with cells transfected with the control plasmid alone. The oocytes were impaled by two microelectrodes, one providing the clamp current and the other measuring the membrane potential. The experimental chamber had a volume of 30 µl, and solution changes were 90% complete in 5 s given a flow rate of 12 µl s−1. The solutions were fed into the chamber via a mechanical valve with a dead space of 5 µl. The recording solution contained 90 mm NaCl, 2 mmKCl, 1 mm CaCl2, 1 mmMgCl2, 5 mm Hepes, pH 7.4. In substitution experiments, sodium ions were replaced by equimolar lithium or choline ions. Two-electrode voltage clamp recordings were performed at room temperature with a Dagan clampator interfaced to an IBM-compatible PC using a DigiData 1200 A/D converter and pCLAMP 6.0 (Axon Instruments). Electrodes were pulled from borosilicate glass capillaries to a resistance of 0.5–2 megaohms and were filled with 1 m KCl. SKF89976A hydrochloride was obtained from Tocris Cookson Ltd. (Bristol, United Kingdom). The [3H]GABA uptake data and the GABA-induced currents were analyzed by nonlinear regression analysis using Prism 3.0 from GraphPad Software (San Diego, CA). For analysis of the transporter-mediated transient current, the capacitative charge movements (Q) were calculated by integration of the transporter transient currents at each membrane potential with the background (ChCl substitution ± Zn2+) subtracted (9Mager S. Naeve J. Quick M. Labarca C. Davidson N. Lester H.A. Neuron. 1993; 10: 177-188Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (275) Google Scholar). The time integral of the transient currents was calculated in SigmaPlot (version 5.0, SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL) after deduction of the steady-state contribution. The Q was then plotted against the membrane potential (Vm), and the resultingQ/Vm relationship was fitted to the Boltzmann equation (Q − Qhyp =Qmax/(1 + exp(zδ(Vm −V0.5)F/RT)).Qmax corresponds to the maximum charge movement defined as Qdep − Qhyp, where Qdep and Qhyp areQ at depolarizing and hyperpolarizing limits, respectively;z is the charge of the particle moving; δ is the fraction of the membrane field through which the charge moves, F is the Faraday constant; R is the gas constant; T is the absolute temperature; and V0.5 is the voltage at which the charge movements are half-completed. TheQ/V relationships were normalized by setting the charge movements observed upon the voltage jump to +50 mV to one and the charge movements observed upon the voltage jump to −150 mV to zero. All means are given as the means ± S.E. or mean ± S.E. interval throughout the manuscript. S.E. intervals were calculated from the S.E. of the means of pKm and pIC50 determined by nonlinear regression analysis. Previously we have demonstrated that the hDAT transiently expressed in COS-7 cells is inhibited by Zn2+ in low micromolar concentrations with an IC50 value of around 1 µm for inhibition of [3H]dopamine uptake (20Norregaard L. Frederiksen D. Nielsen E.O. Gether U. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 4266-4273Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar). This inhibition is due to the presence of an endogenous Zn2+ binding site comprised of three Zn2+coordinating residues: His193, His375, and Glu396 (20Norregaard L. Frederiksen D. Nielsen E.O. Gether U. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 4266-4273Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar, 21Loland C.J. Norregaard L. Gether U. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 36928-36934Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). In contrast to hDAT, the rGAT-1 is insensitive to Zn2+ in low micromolar concentrations. At higher concentrations (millimolar), [3H]GABA uptake was inhibited, but this inhibition can most likely be attributed to nonspecific toxic effects of Zn2+ (Fig. 2) (29Frederickson C.J. Int. Rev. Neurobiol. 1989; 31: 145-238Crossref PubMed Scopus (953) Google Scholar). To probe the structural similarity between the hDAT and rGAT-1 we attempted first to transfer the endogenous site of the hDAT to the rGAT-1 by introducing histidines in positions 177 (Y177H) and 349 (T349H) corresponding to His193 and His375 in hDAT, respectively (Fig. 1). The third coordinating residue Glu396 in the endogenous hDAT binding site is conserved in rGAT-1 (Glu370). Unfortunately mutation of Tyr177 caused the mutant transporter to be nonfunctional (data not shown) making us unable to establish a Zn2+ binding site in rGAT-1 equivalent to the endogenous hDAT site. Instead we investigated the possibility of transferring artificial bidentate Zn2+ sites engineered between TM 7 and 8 from hDAT to GAT-1. Recently we have shown that introduction of a histidine in position 396 in hDAT generates an inhibitory Zn2+ binding site involving this histidine and His375 (21Loland C.J. Norregaard L. Gether U. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 36928-36934Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). As shown in Fig.2, introduction of histidines in the corresponding positions in GAT-1 (T349H/E370H) resulted in potent inhibition of [3H]GABA uptake by Zn2+(IC50 = 35 (range 32–39) µm, TableI). Mutation of Glu370 to histidine (E370H) alone did not increase the apparent Zn2+affinity, and mutation of Thr349 to histidine (T349H) alone caused only a 3–4-fold increase in apparent Zn2+ affinity (Fig. 1 and Table I). This is consistent with Zn2+ being coordinated in a bidentate fashion between both residues. Of interest, the slight 3–4-fold increase in apparent Zn2+ affinity in T349H may reflect low affinity coordination of Zn2+ between the histidine in position 349 and Glu370.Figure 1Two-dimensional representation of therGAT-1. The residues in the top of TM 7 and 8 that have been mutated to either histidine (T349H and E370H) or cysteine (Q374C) areenlarged and marked in black. BALB/c is a susceptible strain for the development of gamma-ray induced mouse thymic lymphoma whereas MSM shows resistance. Association analysis of 220 backcross mice between the two strains using 67 markers was carried out to identify loci involved in the control of susceptibility. The genotype of mice with lymphoma showed excess heterozygosity relative to MSM homozygosity at D2Mit15 and D4Mit12 and was skewed toward MSM-derived alleles at D5Mit5. The P values in Mantel-Cox test were 0.0048 (D2Mit15), 0.0034 (D4Mit12) and 0.0048 (D5Mit5), suggesting association at the three loci in the susceptibility. Cooperative effect on lymphomagenesis was also observed among the three loci. To obtain independent evidence for linkage at D4Mit12, we made partially congenic mice in which a D4Mit12 region in BALB/c was replaced by MSM-derived homolog. Examination for the lymphoma susceptibility in 78 progeny of the congenic mice confirmed the effect of the locus near D4Mit12 (P=0.0037). The result, together with the linkage analysis, shows that the locus near D4Mit12 is regarded as a confirmed linkage but the other two loci as marginally suggestive.

There is evidence that protein kinase C delta (PKCdelta) is a tumor suppressor, although its physiological role has not been elucidated so far. Since important anti-proliferative signals are mediated by cell-cell contacts we studied whether PKCdelta is involved in contact-dependent inhibition of growth in human (FH109) and murine (NIH3T3) fibroblasts. Cell-cell contacts were imitated by the addition of glutardialdehyde-fixed cells to sparsely seeded fibroblasts. Downregulation of the PKC isoforms alpha, delta, epsilon, and mu after prolonged treatment with 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate (TPA, 0.1 microM) resulted in a significant release from contact-inhibition in FH109 cells. Bryostatin 1 selectively prevented TPA-induced PKCdelta-downregulation and reversed TPA-induced release from contact-inhibition arguing for a role of PKCdelta in contact-inhibition. In accordance, the PKCdelta specific inhibitor Rottlerin (1 microM) totally abolished contact-inhibition. Interestingly, immunofluorescence revealed a rapid translocation of PKCdelta to the nucleus when cultures reached confluence with a peak in early-mid G1 phase. Nuclear translocation of PKCdelta in response to cell-cell contacts could also be demonstrated after subcellular fractionation by Western blotting and by measuring PKCdelta-activity after immunoprecipitation. Transient transfection of NIH3T3 cells with a dominant negative mutant of PKCdelta induced a transformed phenotype. We conclude that PKCdelta is involved in contact-dependent inhibition of growth.

Tyrosine phosphorylation is one of the major mechanisms involved in the intracellular propagation of external signals. Strategies aimed at interfering with this process might allow the control of several cellular phenotypes. SH2 domains mediate protein-protein interactions by recognizing phosphotyrosine (pY) residues in the context of specific phosphopeptides. We created an SH2-scaffolded repertoire library by randomly mutagenizing five critical amino acid positions in the specificity-determining region of the PLCgamma C-terminal SH2 domain. Synthetic SH2 domains were selected from the library using biotinylated phosphopeptides derived from a natural PLCgamma-SH2 ligand as well as unrelated SH2 ligands. The isolated SH2s displayed high binding affinity constants for the selecting peptides and were capable of interacting with the corresponding proteins.

Ankyrin defects are the most common cause of hereditary spherocytosis (HS). In several kindreds with recessive, ankyrin-deficient HS, mutations have been identified in the ankyrin promoter that have been proposed to decrease ankyrin synthesis. We analyzed the effects of two mutations, −108T to C and −108T to C in cis with −153G to A, on ankyrin expression. No difference between wild type and mutant promoters was demonstrated in transfection or gel shift assays in vitro. Transgenic mice with a wild type ankyrin promoter linked to a humanAγ-globin gene expressed γ-globin in 100% of erythrocytes in a copy number-dependent, position-independent manner. Transgenic mice with the mutant −108 promoter demonstrated variegated γ-globin expression, but showed copy number-dependent and position-independent expression similar to wild type. Severe effects in ankyrin expression were seen in mice with the linked −108/−153 mutations. Three transgenic lines had undetectable levels of Aγ-globin mRNA, indicating position-dependent expression, and four lines expressed significantly lower levels of Aγ-globin mRNA than wild type. Two of four expressing lines showed variegated γ-globin expression, and there was no correlation between transgene copy number and RNA level, indicating copy number-independent expression. These data are the first demonstration of functional defects caused by HS-related, ankyrin gene promoter mutations. Ankyrin defects are the most common cause of hereditary spherocytosis (HS). These data are the first demonstration of functional defects caused by HS-related, ankyrin gene promoter mutations. hereditary spherocytosis polymerase chain reaction base pair(s) ankyrin Hereditary spherocytosis (HS)1 is a common hemolytic anemia characterized by the presence of spherically shaped erythrocytes on peripheral blood smear. The principal cellular defect in HS is loss of erythrocyte membrane surface area relative to intracellular volume, accounting for the spherical shape as well as decreased deformability of the erythrocyte (1Gallagher P.G. Jarolim P. Hematology: Basic Principles and Practice. W. B. Saunders Co., Philadelphia1999: 576-610Google Scholar). The primary biochemical defects in HS reside in the proteins of the erythrocyte membrane, particularly those proteins involved in the interactions between the membrane skeleton and the lipid bilayer: ankyrin, α and β spectrin, band 3, and protein 4.2 (2Iolascon A. Miraglia del Giudice E. Perrotta S. Alloisio N. Morle L. Delaunay J. Haematologica. 1998; 83: 240-257PubMed Google Scholar, 3Tse W.T. Lux S.E. Br. J. Haematol. 1999; 104: 2-13Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar). In two thirds to three quarters of cases, HS is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion (1Gallagher P.G. Jarolim P. Hematology: Basic Principles and Practice. W. B. Saunders Co., Philadelphia1999: 576-610Google Scholar, 2Iolascon A. Miraglia del Giudice E. Perrotta S. Alloisio N. Morle L. Delaunay J. In the remaining patients, HS is inherited in a recessive fashion or is the result of a de novo mutation. Ankyrin-1 (ANK1, Mendelian Inheritance in Man 182900) deficiency is one of the most common abnormalities found in the erythrocyte membranes of HS patients (5Savvides P. Shalev O. John K.M. Lux S.E. Blood. 1993; 82: 2953-2960Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 6Saad S.T. Costa F.F. Vicentim D.L. Salles T.S. Pranke P.H. Br. J. Haematol. 1994; 88: 295-299Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 8703-8706Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 8Peters L.L. Lux S.E. Semin. Hematol. 1993; 30: 85-118PubMed Google Scholar). Studies have revealed that abnormalities of the ankyrin gene, primarily frameshift or nonsense mutations, are the most common cause of typical, dominant HS (3Tse W.T. Lux S.E. Br. J. Haematol. 1999; 104: 2-13Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar, 9Eber S.W. Gonzalez J.M. Lux M.L. Scarpa A.L. Tse W.T. Dornwell M. Herbers J. Kugler W. Ozcan R. Pekrun A. Gallagher P.G. One molecular mechanism that could lead to ankyrin deficiency is a mutation in the ankyrin erythroid promoter leading to decreased ankyrin synthesis. Several reports have identified sequence variations in the ankyrin gene promoter in individuals with recessively inherited, ankyrin-deficient HS (4Miraglia del Giudice E. Nobili B. Francese M. D'Urso L. Iolascon A. Eber S. Perrotta S. Br. J. Haematol. 2001; 112: 42-47Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar, 9Eber S.W. Gonzalez J.M. Lux M.L. Scarpa A.L. Tse W.T. Dornwell M. Herbers J. Whether these are disease causing mutations or are merely polymorphisms in linkage disequilibrium with as yet unidentified mutations is unknown, as it is difficult to assess the effect of promoter mutations on ankyrin gene expression in affected HS patients. To address this question, we have analyzed the effect of two HS-associated, ankyrin gene promoter mutations in vitro and in vivo. The first mutation, a T to C substitution at position −108, was discovered in the heterozygous state in four of seven German families with ankyrin-deficient, recessive HS (9Eber S.W. Gonzalez J.M. Lux M.L. Scarpa A.L. Tse W.T. Dornwell M. Herbers J. Kugler W. Ozcan R. Pekrun A. Gallagher P.G. Schroter W. Forget B.G. Lux S.E. Nat. Genet. 1996; 13: 214-218Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar). In two of the four kindreds, mutations in the coding region of the ankyrin gene were discovered in trans, and the mutation was silent in the heterozygous state. In this mostly German HS population, the allele frequency was estimated to be 29% in HS patients and 2.0% in normal individuals. This mutation has also been associated with ankyrin-deficient, nondominantly inherited HS in Italy (4Miraglia del Giudice E. Nobili B. Francese M. D'Urso L. Iolascon A. Eber S. Perrotta S. Br. J. Haematol. 2001; 112: 42-47Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). The second mutation, a G to A substitution at position −153, was discovered in the heterozygous state in a Brazilian kindred with ankyrin-deficient, recessive HS (11Leite R.C. Basseres D.S. Ferreira J.S. Alberto F.L. Costa F.F. Saad S.T. Hum. Mutat. 2000; 16: 529Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). The −153 substitution was always found in cis to the previously reported −108T to C ankyrin promoter mutation. These linked substitutions were silent in the heterozygous state. No individuals with the −153 mutation alone were detected. In a control Brazilian population, the allelic frequency of the −108/−153 allele was 2.4% and the −108 allele was 1.4%. We used this ankyrin promoter/human Aγ-globin reporter transgenic mouse model as a system to study the effect of the spherocytosis-associated promoter mutations in vivo.Significant abnormalities in reporter gene mRNA and protein expression were seen, the first demonstration of functional defects caused by HS-related ankyrin gene promoter mutations. These promoter mutations may represent a common pathogenetic mechanism of recessive HS in ankyrin-deficient patients. Romana M. Tse W.T. Lux S.E. Forget B.G. Blood. 2000; 96: 1136-1143Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). All plasmids tested were purified using Qiagen columns (Qiagen, Inc., Chatsworth, CA) or cesium chloride plasmid purification, and at least two preparations of each plasmid were tested in triplicate. 107 K562 or HEL cells were transfected by electroporation with a single pulse of 300 V at 960 microfarads with 20 μg of test plasmid and 0.5 μg of pCMVβ, a mammalian reporter plasmid expressing β-galactosidase driven by the human cytomegalovirus immediate early gene promoter (CLONTECH, Palo Alto, CA) to normalize for transfection efficiency. (19Hogan B. Costantini F. Lacy E. Manipulating the Mouse Embryo: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1986Google Scholar) and Sabatino et al. Fertilized eggs were collected from superovulated FVB/N female mice (Taconic Farms, Germantown, NY) ∼9 h after mating to CBy6F1 male mice (Jackson Laboratory, Bar Harbor, ME). Fragments for microinjection were separated on an agarose gel, electroeluted, and purified with an Elutip-d minicolumn (Schleicher & Schuell). The fragments were diluted to a concentration of 2 ng/μl in 10 mm Tris, 0.25 mm EDTA (pH 7.5), and ∼ 2 pl was injected into the male pronucleus of fertilized eggs. The injected eggs were transferred to psuedopregnant CByB6/F1 foster mothers. Founder animals were identified by Southern analysis of DNA extracted from tail biopsies by probing with an Ank/Aγ-globin probe. Founder animals were crossed to FVB/N mice for propagation. Copy number was determined by comparing the γ-globin signals from Southern blot analysis of transgenic mouse and K562 DNA using a Molecular Dynamics PhosphorImager. Statistical analysis of copy number and expression data was analyzed by linear regression using GraphPad Prism® version 2.0 software. Total cellular RNA was extracted from adult reticulocytes, obtained by collecting 200 μl of blood from phlebotomized animals, using TRIZOL reagent according to the manufacturer’s specifications (Life Technologies, Inc.). Linear DNA templates for RNase protection assays were prepared by restriction enzyme digestion of cesium chloride purified plasmid preparations. Riboprobe one, which contains sequences for both exon 2 of the humanAγ-globin gene and exon 2 of the murine α-globin gene, was linearized with BglII (Fig. 2 B). This riboprobe ensures that both the human Aγ-globin and murine α-globin sequences are labeled to equal specific activity, allowing direct comparison of human Aγ-globin and murine α-globin mRNA levels.
